trans-unit.source: Hybrid on-premises/cloud application (.NET) | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Hybrid on-premises/cloud application (.NET) | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to create a .NET on-premises/cloud hybrid application using the Azure Service Bus relay.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to create a .NET on-premises/cloud hybrid application using the Azure Service Bus relay.

trans-unit.source: .NET on-premises/cloud hybrid application using Azure Service Bus relay
trans-unit.target: .NET on-premises/cloud hybrid application using Azure Service Bus relay

trans-unit.source: Introduction
trans-unit.target: Introduction

trans-unit.source: Developing hybrid cloud applications with Microsoft Azure is easy using
trans-unit.target: Developing hybrid cloud applications with Microsoft Azure is easy using

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio 2013 and the free Azure SDK for .NET.
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio 2013 and the free Azure SDK for .NET.

trans-unit.source: This article
trans-unit.target: This article

trans-unit.source: assumes you have no prior experience using Azure.
trans-unit.target: assumes you have no prior experience using Azure.

trans-unit.source: In less than
trans-unit.target: In less than

trans-unit.source: 30 minutes, you will have an application that uses multiple Azure resources up and running in the cloud.
trans-unit.target: 30 minutes, you will have an application that uses multiple Azure resources up and running in the cloud.

trans-unit.target: You will learn:

trans-unit.target: How the Service Bus relay helps with hybrid solutions

trans-unit.source: Business solutions are typically composed of a combination of custom
trans-unit.target: Business solutions are typically composed of a combination of custom

trans-unit.source: code written to tackle new and unique business requirements and existing
trans-unit.target: code written to tackle new and unique business requirements and existing

trans-unit.source: functionality provided by solutions and systems that are already in
trans-unit.target: functionality provided by solutions and systems that are already in

trans-unit.source: place.
trans-unit.target: place.

trans-unit.target: Solution architects are starting to use the cloud for easier handling of

trans-unit.source: scale requirements and lower operational costs.
trans-unit.target: scale requirements and lower operational costs.

trans-unit.source: In doing so, they find
trans-unit.target: In doing so, they find

trans-unit.source: that existing service assets they'd like to leverage as building blocks
trans-unit.target: that existing service assets they'd like to leverage as building blocks

trans-unit.source: for their solutions are inside the corporate firewall and out of easy
trans-unit.target: for their solutions are inside the corporate firewall and out of easy

trans-unit.source: reach for access by the cloud solution.
trans-unit.target: reach for access by the cloud solution.

trans-unit.source: Many internal services are not
trans-unit.target: Many internal services are not

trans-unit.source: built or hosted in a way that they can be easily exposed at the
trans-unit.target: built or hosted in a way that they can be easily exposed at the

trans-unit.target: corporate network edge.

trans-unit.source: The Service Bus relay is designed for the use-case of taking existing
trans-unit.target: The Service Bus relay is designed for the use-case of taking existing

trans-unit.source: Windows Communication Foundation (WCF) web services and making those
trans-unit.target: Windows Communication Foundation (WCF) web services and making those

trans-unit.source: services securely accessible to solutions that reside outside the
trans-unit.target: services securely accessible to solutions that reside outside the

trans-unit.source: corporate perimeter without requiring intrusive changes to the corporate
trans-unit.target: corporate perimeter without requiring intrusive changes to the corporate

trans-unit.source: network infrastructure.
trans-unit.target: network infrastructure.

trans-unit.source: Such Service Bus relay services are still hosted
trans-unit.target: Such Service Bus relay services are still hosted

trans-unit.source: inside their existing environment, but they delegate listening for
trans-unit.target: inside their existing environment, but they delegate listening for

trans-unit.source: incoming sessions and requests to the cloud-hosted Service Bus.
trans-unit.target: incoming sessions and requests to the cloud-hosted Service Bus.

trans-unit.source: Service Bus also protects those services from unauthorized access by using <link><linkText>Shared Access Signature</linkText><title></title></link> (SAS) authentication.
trans-unit.target: Service Bus also protects those services from unauthorized access by using <link><linkText>Shared Access Signature</linkText><title></title></link> (SAS) authentication.

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, you will create an ASP.NET MVC website that enables you to see a list of products on the product inventory page.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, you will create an ASP.NET MVC website that enables you to see a list of products on the product inventory page.

trans-unit.source: The tutorial assumes that you have product information in an existing
trans-unit.target: The tutorial assumes that you have product information in an existing

trans-unit.target: on-premises system, and uses the Service Bus relay to reach into that

trans-unit.source: system.
trans-unit.target: system.

trans-unit.source: This is simulated by a web service that runs in a simple
trans-unit.target: This is simulated by a web service that runs in a simple

trans-unit.source: console application and is backed by an in-memory set of products.
trans-unit.target: console application and is backed by an in-memory set of products.

trans-unit.target: the web role running in the Azure datacenter will indeed call

trans-unit.target: into your computer, even though your computer will almost certainly

trans-unit.target: reside behind at least one firewall and a network address translation

trans-unit.source: Set up the development environment
trans-unit.target: Set up the development environment

trans-unit.source: Before you can begin developing your Azure application, get the tools and set up your development environment.
trans-unit.target: Before you can begin developing your Azure application, get the tools and set up your development environment.

trans-unit.source: Install the Azure SDK for .NET at <link><linkText>Get Tools and SDK[]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Install the Azure SDK for .NET at <link><linkText>Get Tools and SDK[]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Click Install the SDK for the version of Visual Studio you are using.
trans-unit.target: Click Install the SDK for the version of Visual Studio you are using.

trans-unit.source: The steps in this tutorial use Visual Studio 2013.
trans-unit.target: The steps in this tutorial use Visual Studio 2013.

trans-unit.source: When prompted to run or save the installer, click Run.
trans-unit.target: When prompted to run or save the installer, click Run.

trans-unit.source: In the Web Platform Installer, click Install and proceed with the installation.
trans-unit.target: In the Web Platform Installer, click Install and proceed with the installation.

trans-unit.source: Once the installation is complete, you will have everything
trans-unit.target: Once the installation is complete, you will have everything

trans-unit.source: necessary to start to develop the app.
trans-unit.target: necessary to start to develop the app.

trans-unit.source: The SDK includes tools that let you
trans-unit.target: The SDK includes tools that let you

trans-unit.source: easily develop Azure applications in Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: easily develop Azure applications in Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: If you
trans-unit.target: If you

trans-unit.target: do not have Visual Studio installed, the SDK also installs the free

trans-unit.target: Visual Studio Express.

trans-unit.source: Create a service namespace
trans-unit.target: Create a service namespace

trans-unit.source: To begin using Service Bus features in Azure, you must first create a service namespace.
trans-unit.target: To begin using Service Bus features in Azure, you must first create a service namespace.

trans-unit.source: A namespace provides a scoping container for addressing Service Bus resources within your application.
trans-unit.target: A namespace provides a scoping container for addressing Service Bus resources within your application.

trans-unit.source: You can manage namespaces and Service Bus messaging entities using either the <link><linkText>Azure portal[]</linkText><title></title></link> or the Visual Studio Server Explorer, but you can only create new namespaces from within the portal.
trans-unit.target: You can manage namespaces and Service Bus messaging entities using either the <link><linkText>Azure portal[]</linkText><title></title></link> or the Visual Studio Server Explorer, but you can only create new namespaces from within the portal.

trans-unit.source: To create a namespace using the portal:
trans-unit.target: To create a namespace using the portal:

trans-unit.source: Sign in to the <link><linkText>Azure portal[]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Sign in to the <link><linkText>Azure portal[]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: In the left navigation pane of the Azure portal, click
trans-unit.target: In the left navigation pane of the Azure portal, click

trans-unit.source: Service Bus.
trans-unit.target: Service Bus.

trans-unit.source: In the lower pane of the Azure portal, click Create.
trans-unit.target: In the lower pane of the Azure portal, click Create.

trans-unit.source: In the Add a new namespace dialog box, enter a namespace name.
trans-unit.target: In the Add a new namespace dialog box, enter a namespace name.

trans-unit.source: The system immediately checks to see if the name is available.
trans-unit.target: The system immediately checks to see if the name is available.

trans-unit.source: After making sure the namespace name is available, choose the
trans-unit.target: After making sure the namespace name is available, choose the

trans-unit.source: country or region in which your namespace should be hosted (make
trans-unit.target: country or region in which your namespace should be hosted (make

trans-unit.source: sure you use the same country/region in which you are deploying your
trans-unit.target: sure you use the same country/region in which you are deploying your

trans-unit.source: compute resources).
trans-unit.target: compute resources).

trans-unit.source: Pick the same region that you intend to choose for
trans-unit.target: Pick the same region that you intend to choose for

trans-unit.source: deploying your application.
trans-unit.target: deploying your application.

trans-unit.source: This will give you the best performance.
trans-unit.target: This will give you the best performance.

trans-unit.source: Leave the other fields in the dialog box with their default values (Messaging and Standard tier), then click the check mark.
trans-unit.target: Leave the other fields in the dialog box with their default values (Messaging and Standard tier), then click the check mark.

trans-unit.source: The system now creates your namespace and enables it.
trans-unit.target: The system now creates your namespace and enables it.

trans-unit.source: You might have to wait several minutes as the system provisions resources for your account.
trans-unit.target: You might have to wait several minutes as the system provisions resources for your account.

trans-unit.source: The namespace you created will appear in the Azure portal, though it may take a moment to activate.
trans-unit.target: The namespace you created will appear in the Azure portal, though it may take a moment to activate.

trans-unit.source: Wait until the status is Active before moving on.
trans-unit.target: Wait until the status is Active before moving on.

trans-unit.source: Obtain the default management credentials for the namespace
trans-unit.target: Obtain the default management credentials for the namespace

trans-unit.source: In order to perform management operations on the new namespace, such as creating messaging entities, you must obtain credentials for the namespace.
trans-unit.target: In order to perform management operations on the new namespace, such as creating messaging entities, you must obtain credentials for the namespace.

trans-unit.source: In the main window, click the name of your service namespace.
trans-unit.target: In the main window, click the name of your service namespace.

trans-unit.source: Click Connection Information.
trans-unit.target: Click Connection Information.

trans-unit.source: In the Access connection information pane, find the connection string that contains the SAS key and key name.
trans-unit.target: In the Access connection information pane, find the connection string that contains the SAS key and key name.

trans-unit.source: Make a note of these credentials, or copy them to the clipboard.
trans-unit.target: Make a note of these credentials, or copy them to the clipboard.

trans-unit.source: Make your application ready to deploy to Azure
trans-unit.target: Make your application ready to deploy to Azure

trans-unit.source: You can deploy your application to an Azure cloud service or to an Azure website.
trans-unit.target: You can deploy your application to an Azure cloud service or to an Azure website.

trans-unit.source: To learn more about the difference between websites and cloud services, see <link><linkText>Azure Execution Models[executionmodels]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: To learn more about the difference between websites and cloud services, see <link><linkText>Azure Execution Models[executionmodels]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: To learn how to deploy the application to an Azure website, see <link><linkText>Deploying an ASP.NET Web Application to an Azure Website</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: To learn how to deploy the application to an Azure website, see <link><linkText>Deploying an ASP.NET Web Application to an Azure Website</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: This section contains detailed steps for deploying the application to an Azure cloud service.
trans-unit.target: This section contains detailed steps for deploying the application to an Azure cloud service.

trans-unit.source: To deploy your application to a cloud service, you'll add a cloud service project deployment project to the solution.
trans-unit.target: To deploy your application to a cloud service, you'll add a cloud service project deployment project to the solution.

trans-unit.source: The deployment project contains configuration information that is needed to properly run your application in the cloud.
trans-unit.target: The deployment project contains configuration information that is needed to properly run your application in the cloud.

trans-unit.source: To make your application deployable to the cloud, right-click the ProductsPortal project in Solution Explorer and click Convert, then click Convert to Microsoft Azure Cloud Service Project.
trans-unit.target: To make your application deployable to the cloud, right-click the ProductsPortal project in Solution Explorer and click Convert, then click Convert to Microsoft Azure Cloud Service Project.

trans-unit.source: To test your application, press F5.
trans-unit.target: To test your application, press F5.

trans-unit.source: This will start the Azure compute emulator.
trans-unit.target: This will start the Azure compute emulator.

trans-unit.source: The compute emulator uses the local computer to emulate your application running in Azure.
trans-unit.target: The compute emulator uses the local computer to emulate your application running in Azure.

trans-unit.source: You can confirm the emulator has started by looking at the system tray.
trans-unit.target: You can confirm the emulator has started by looking at the system tray.

trans-unit.source: A browser will still display your application running locally, and it will look and function the same way it did when you ran it earlier as a regular ASP.NET MVC 4 application.
trans-unit.target: A browser will still display your application running locally, and it will look and function the same way it did when you ran it earlier as a regular ASP.NET MVC 4 application.

trans-unit.source: Put the pieces together
trans-unit.target: Put the pieces together

trans-unit.source: The next step is to hook up the on-premises products server with the ASP.NET MVC application.
trans-unit.target: The next step is to hook up the on-premises products server with the ASP.NET MVC application.

trans-unit.source: If it is not already open, in Visual Studio re-open the ProductsPortal project you created in the "Creating an ASP.NET MVC Application" section.
trans-unit.target: If it is not already open, in Visual Studio re-open the ProductsPortal project you created in the "Creating an ASP.NET MVC Application" section.

trans-unit.source: Similar to the step in the "Create an On-Premises Server" section, add the NuGet package to the project References.
trans-unit.target: Similar to the step in the "Create an On-Premises Server" section, add the NuGet package to the project References.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, right-click References, then click Manage NuGet Packages.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, right-click References, then click Manage NuGet Packages.

trans-unit.source: Search for "Service Bus" and select the Microsoft Azure Service Bus item.
trans-unit.target: Search for "Service Bus" and select the Microsoft Azure Service Bus item.

trans-unit.source: Then complete the installation and close this dialog box.
trans-unit.target: Then complete the installation and close this dialog box.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, right-click the ProductsPortal project, then click Add, then Existing Item.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, right-click the ProductsPortal project, then click Add, then Existing Item.

trans-unit.source: Navigate to the ProductsContract.cs file from the ProductsServer console project.
trans-unit.target: Navigate to the ProductsContract.cs file from the ProductsServer console project.

trans-unit.source: Click to highlight ProductsContract.cs.
trans-unit.target: Click to highlight ProductsContract.cs.

trans-unit.source: Click the down arrow next to Add, then click Add as Link.
trans-unit.target: Click the down arrow next to Add, then click Add as Link.

trans-unit.source: Now open the HomeController.cs file in the Visual Studio editor and replace the namespace definition with the following code.
trans-unit.target: Now open the HomeController.cs file in the Visual Studio editor and replace the namespace definition with the following code.

trans-unit.source: Be sure to replace yourServiceNamespace with the name of your service namespace, and yourKey with your SAS key.
trans-unit.target: Be sure to replace yourServiceNamespace with the name of your service namespace, and yourKey with your SAS key.

trans-unit.source: This will enable the client to call the on-premises service, returning the result of the call.
trans-unit.target: This will enable the client to call the on-premises service, returning the result of the call.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, right-click the ProductsPortalsolution, click Add, then click Existing Project.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, right-click the ProductsPortalsolution, click Add, then click Existing Project.

trans-unit.source: Navigate to the ProductsServer project, then double-click the ProductsServer.csproj solution file to add it.
trans-unit.target: Navigate to the ProductsServer project, then double-click the ProductsServer.csproj solution file to add it.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, right-click the ProductsPortal solution and click Properties.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, right-click the ProductsPortal solution and click Properties.

trans-unit.source: On the left side, click Startup Project.
trans-unit.target: On the left side, click Startup Project.

trans-unit.source: On the right side, click Multiple startup projects.
trans-unit.target: On the right side, click Multiple startup projects.

trans-unit.source: Ensure that ProductsServer, ProductsPortal.Azure, and ProductsPortal appear, in that order, with Start set as the action for ProductsServer and ProductsPortal.Azure, and None set as the action for ProductsPortal.
trans-unit.target: Ensure that ProductsServer, ProductsPortal.Azure, and ProductsPortal appear, in that order, with Start set as the action for ProductsServer and ProductsPortal.Azure, and None set as the action for ProductsPortal.

trans-unit.source: Still in the Properties dialog box, click ProjectDependencies on the left side.
trans-unit.target: Still in the Properties dialog box, click ProjectDependencies on the left side.

trans-unit.source: In the Projects list, click ProductsServer.
trans-unit.target: In the Projects list, click ProductsServer.

trans-unit.source: Ensure that ProductsPortal is not selected, and ProductsPortal.Azure is selected.
trans-unit.target: Ensure that ProductsPortal is not selected, and ProductsPortal.Azure is selected.

trans-unit.source: Then click OK:
trans-unit.target: Then click OK:

trans-unit.source: Run the application
trans-unit.target: Run the application

trans-unit.source: From the File menu in Visual Studio, click Save All.
trans-unit.target: From the File menu in Visual Studio, click Save All.

trans-unit.source: Press F5 to build and run the application.
trans-unit.target: Press F5 to build and run the application.

trans-unit.source: The on-premises server (the ProductsServer console application) should start first, then the ProductsWeb application should start in a browser window, as shown in the following screen shot.
trans-unit.target: The on-premises server (the ProductsServer console application) should start first, then the ProductsWeb application should start in a browser window, as shown in the following screen shot.

trans-unit.source: This time, you will see that the product inventory lists data retrieved from the product service on-premises system.
trans-unit.target: This time, you will see that the product inventory lists data retrieved from the product service on-premises system.

trans-unit.source: Deploy your application to Azure
trans-unit.target: Deploy your application to Azure

trans-unit.source: Right-click the ProductsPortal project in Solution Explorer and then click Publish to Microsoft Azure.
trans-unit.target: Right-click the ProductsPortal project in Solution Explorer and then click Publish to Microsoft Azure.

trans-unit.source: You might have to sign in to see all your subscriptions.
trans-unit.target: You might have to sign in to see all your subscriptions.

trans-unit.source: Click Sign in to see more subscriptions:
trans-unit.target: Click Sign in to see more subscriptions:

trans-unit.source: Sign in using your Microsoft Account.
trans-unit.target: Sign in using your Microsoft Account.

trans-unit.source: Click Next.
trans-unit.target: Click Next.

trans-unit.source: If your subscription doesn't already contain any hosted services, you will be asked to create one.
trans-unit.target: If your subscription doesn't already contain any hosted services, you will be asked to create one.

trans-unit.source: The hosted service acts as a container for your application within your Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: The hosted service acts as a container for your application within your Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: Enter a name that identifies your application and choose the region for which the application should be optimized.
trans-unit.target: Enter a name that identifies your application and choose the region for which the application should be optimized.

trans-unit.source: (You can expect faster loading times for users accessing it from this region.)
trans-unit.target: (You can expect faster loading times for users accessing it from this region.)

trans-unit.source: Select the hosted service to which you would like to publish your application.
trans-unit.target: Select the hosted service to which you would like to publish your application.

trans-unit.source: Keep the defaults as shown below for the remaining settings.
trans-unit.target: Keep the defaults as shown below for the remaining settings.

trans-unit.source: Click Next.
trans-unit.target: Click Next.

trans-unit.source: On the last page, click Publish to start the deployment process.
trans-unit.target: On the last page, click Publish to start the deployment process.

trans-unit.source: This will take approximately 5-7 minutes.
trans-unit.target: This will take approximately 5-7 minutes.

trans-unit.source: Since this is the first time you are publishing, Azure provisions a virtual machine (VM), performs security hardening, creates a Web role on the VM to host your application, deploys your code to that Web role, and finally configures the load balancer and networking so your application is available to the public.
trans-unit.target: Since this is the first time you are publishing, Azure provisions a virtual machine (VM), performs security hardening, creates a Web role on the VM to host your application, deploys your code to that Web role, and finally configures the load balancer and networking so your application is available to the public.

trans-unit.source: While publishing is in progress you will be able to monitor the activity in the Azure Activity Log window, which is typically docked to the bottom of Visual Studio or Visual Web Developer.
trans-unit.target: While publishing is in progress you will be able to monitor the activity in the Azure Activity Log window, which is typically docked to the bottom of Visual Studio or Visual Web Developer.

trans-unit.source: When deployment is complete, you can view your website by clicking the Website URL link in the monitoring window.
trans-unit.target: When deployment is complete, you can view your website by clicking the Website URL link in the monitoring window.

trans-unit.source: Your website depends on your on-premises server, so you must run the ProductsServer application locally for the website to function properly.
trans-unit.target: Your website depends on your on-premises server, so you must run the ProductsServer application locally for the website to function properly.

trans-unit.source: As you perform requests on the cloud website, you will see requests coming into your on-premises console application, as indicated by the "GetProducts called" output displayed in the following screen shot.
trans-unit.target: As you perform requests on the cloud website, you will see requests coming into your on-premises console application, as indicated by the "GetProducts called" output displayed in the following screen shot.

trans-unit.source: To learn more about the difference between websites and cloud services, see <link><linkText>Azure Execution Models[executionmodels]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: To learn more about the difference between websites and cloud services, see <link><linkText>Azure Execution Models[executionmodels]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Stop and delete your application
trans-unit.target: Stop and delete your application

trans-unit.source: After deploying your application, you may want to disable it so you
trans-unit.target: After deploying your application, you may want to disable it so you

trans-unit.source: can build and deploy other applications within the free 750
trans-unit.target: can build and deploy other applications within the free 750

trans-unit.source: hours/month (31 days/month) of server time.
trans-unit.target: hours/month (31 days/month) of server time.

trans-unit.source: Azure bills web role instances per hour of server time
trans-unit.target: Azure bills web role instances per hour of server time

trans-unit.source: consumed.
trans-unit.target: consumed.

trans-unit.source: Server time is consumed once your application is deployed,
trans-unit.target: Server time is consumed once your application is deployed,

trans-unit.source: even if the instances are not running and are in the stopped state.
trans-unit.target: even if the instances are not running and are in the stopped state.

trans-unit.source: A free account includes 750 hours/month (31 days/month) of dedicated
trans-unit.target: A free account includes 750 hours/month (31 days/month) of dedicated

trans-unit.source: virtual machine server time for hosting these web role instances.
trans-unit.target: virtual machine server time for hosting these web role instances.

trans-unit.source: The following steps show you how to stop and delete your
trans-unit.target: The following steps show you how to stop and delete your

trans-unit.source: application.
trans-unit.target: application.

trans-unit.source: Sign in to the [Azure portal], click Cloud Services, then click the name of your service.
trans-unit.target: Sign in to the [Azure portal], click Cloud Services, then click the name of your service.

trans-unit.source: Click the Dashboard tab, and then click Stop to temporarily suspend your application.
trans-unit.target: Click the Dashboard tab, and then click Stop to temporarily suspend your application.

trans-unit.source: You will be able to start it again by clicking Start.
trans-unit.target: You will be able to start it again by clicking Start.

trans-unit.source: Click Delete to completely remove your application from Azure with no ability to restore it.
trans-unit.target: Click Delete to completely remove your application from Azure with no ability to restore it.

trans-unit.source: Next steps
trans-unit.target: Next steps

trans-unit.target: To learn more about Service Bus, see the following resources:
